Title: Text Encryption in Android Chat Applications using Elliptical Curve Cryptography (ECC)
Affiliations: Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Natanael, D., Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Faisal, Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suryani, D., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Information technology is an important aspect of human life that has provided comfort and ease in communicating. The most used communication technologies today is the smartphone, which is a mobile phone with the ability of a portable computer. Currently, to communicate each other, people feel more convenience using chat application in a smartphone than calling or short message services (SMS) features. Some of the advantages of chat application are there is no message size limitations, highest number of consumers use it; especially younger demographics,and it also works on mobile web without application download. Due to the convenience of communication using chat apps increases, the security demands are also higher, i.e., a proper cryptography scheme is needed to protect the messages. In this paper, we implement ECC algorithm to secure text message in messaging application of a smartphone. We will adopt the method proposed by Singh1 to create a chat application in Android program that equipped end-to-end encryption. We also give the experimental result of our chat apps performance such as the accuracy of the received text message, average encryption and decryption time. © 2018 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
Author Keywords: Chat Application; Cryptography; Elliptical Curve Cryptography; Text Encryption
Index Keywords: Android (operating system); Application programs; Artificial intelligence; Cellular telephone systems; Message passing; Microcomputers; Mobile security; Smartphones; Text messaging; Communication technologies; Elliptical curve cryptographies; Elliptical Curve Cryptography (ECC); Encryption and decryption; End-to-end encryption; Messaging applications; Short message services; Text encryptions; Cryptography

Title: An Algorithm to Find Square Root of Quadratic Residues over Finite Fields using Primitive Elements
Affiliations: Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9 Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Faisal, Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9 Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Gazali, W., Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9 Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Quadratic residue is an important concept in number theory because it has both theoretical and practical application in mathematics and other areas such as computer science and communication. We also have a same concept of quadratic residue in general finite fields. Finding a square root of a quadratic residue in finite fields is an essential problem in computational algebra. In this paper we present an algorithm of computing square root of quadratic residue in finite fields using a primitive element. © 2017 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: finite field; polynomial; primitive element; quadratic residue; square root
Index Keywords: Algebra; Artificial intelligence; Number theory; Polynomials; Computational algebra; Essential problems; Finite fields; Primitive element; Quadratic residues; Square roots; Computation theory
Funding Text 1: This research was supported by Hibah Binus 2016. We would like to express our thank to all colleagues for giving insight and expertise in this research. We would also like to thank Bina Nusantara University for providing the funding of this research and for giving the opportunity to attend conference.

Title: Distributed Steganography Using Five Pixel Pair Differencing and Modulus Function
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, K.H. Syahdan 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Fendi, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, K.H. Syahdan 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Wibisurya, A., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, K.H. Syahdan 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Faisal, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, K.H. Syahdan 9, Palmerah, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: FPPD steganography is one of steganography techniques that hides secret message by adjusting the difference between pixel pairs in 2x3 blocks. FPPD usually deals with using one cover image to hide any data. To make it practical, a steganography method needs to accommodate concatenated data of different types of media. The steganography method should also allow large data to be distributed on multiple cover images. Therefore, there should be indicator for the start, end, and media type of each component of secret data. The purpose of this research is to develop a FPPD based distributed steganography which allow addition of multiple secret message components across multiple cover images while informing the recipient of the media type of each secret message. This is done by applying a modulus function to to adjust the values of a block to represent the start, end, continuation, and media type of secret messages. The proposed approach results in PSNR value of 37.62, below the benchmark FPPD method. This decrease in PSNR is the result of modification to the pixel value of the reference point to provide means to embed data of different media types into several images. © 2017 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Pixels; distributed; FPPD; Media types; Modulus functions; Pixel values; Reference points; Secret data; Secret messages; Steganography

Title: Auslander reiten quiver of Nakayama algebra type dynkin graph An
Source title: Journal of Mathematical and Fundamental Sciences
Affiliations: Algebra Research Group, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Jalan Ganesha 10 Bandung 40132, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Faisal, Algebra Research Group, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Jalan Ganesha 10 Bandung 40132, Indonesia; Irawati, Algebra Research Group, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Jalan Ganesha 10 Bandung 40132, Indonesia; Muchtadi-Alamsyah, I., Algebra Research Group, Institut Teknologi Bandung, Jalan Ganesha 10 Bandung 40132, Indonesia
Abstract: In this paper we will determine Auslander Reiten quiver of Nakayama algebra with quiver type Dynkin graph An for all natural number n ≥ 2. The AR-quiver is a visualization of module category of finite dimensional algebras. From the AR-quiver of an algebra A we may know all the isomorphism classes of indecomposable modules in mod A and the homomorphism between them. Once we get the general shape of the AR-quiver of this algebra, we will use it to compute a tilting module of this algebra. © 2013 Published by ITB Journal Publisher.
Author Keywords: AR-quiver; Dynkin type A; Nakayama algebra; Quiver
